section.title: about groups
section.para: Users can be listed in groups. Groups allow you to set permissions on the group level instead of having to set permissions for every individual user. Every Unix or Linux distribution will have a graphical tool to manage groups. Novice users are advised to use this graphical tool. More experienced users can use command line tools to manage users, but be careful: Some distributions do not allow the mixed use of GUI and CLI tools to manage groups (YaST in Novell Suse). Senior administrators can edit the relevant files directly with vi or vigr.

section.title: groupadd
section.para: Groups can be created with the groupaddgroupadd(1) command. The example below shows the creation of five (empty) groups.
section.screen: root@laika:~# groupadd tennis root@laika:~# groupadd football root@laika:~# groupadd snooker root@laika:~# groupadd formula1 root@laika:~# groupadd salsa

section.title: /etc/group
section.para: Users can be a member of several groups. Group membership is defined by the /etc/group/etc/group file.
section.screen: root@laika:~# tail -5 /etc/group tennis:x:1006: football:x:1007: snooker:x:1008: formula1:x:1009: salsa:x:1010: root@laika:~#
section.para: The first field is the group's name. The second field is the group's (encrypted) password (can be empty). The third field is the group identification or GIDGID. The fourth field is the list of members, these groups have no members.

section.title: usermod
section.para: Group membership can be modified with the useradd or usermodusermod command.
section.screen: root@laika:~# usermod -a -G tennis inge root@laika:~# usermod -a -G tennis katrien root@laika:~# usermod -a -G salsa katrien root@laika:~# usermod -a -G snooker sandra root@laika:~# usermod -a -G formula1 annelies root@laika:~# tail -5 /etc/group tennis:x:1006:inge,katrien football:x:1007: snooker:x:1008:sandra formula1:x:1009:annelies salsa:x:1010:katrien root@laika:~#
section.para: Be careful when using usermod to add users to groups. By default, the usermod command will remove the user from every group of which he is a member if the group is not listed in the command! Using the -a (append) switch prevents this behaviour.

section.title: groupmod
section.para: You can change the group name with the groupmodgroupmod(1) command.
section.screen: root@laika:~# groupmod -n darts snooker root@laika:~# tail -5 /etc/group tennis:x:1006:inge,katrien football:x:1007: formula1:x:1009:annelies salsa:x:1010:katrien darts:x:1008:sandra

section.title: groupdel
section.para: You can permanently remove a group with the groupdelgroupdel(1) command.

section.title: groups
section.para: A user can type the groupsgroups(1) command to see a list of groups where the user belongs to.

section.title: gpasswd
section.para: You can delegate control of group membership to another user with the gpasswdgpasswd command. In the example below we delegate permissions to add and remove group members to serena for the sports group. Then we su to serena and add harry to the sports group.
section.screen: [root@RHEL4b ~]# gpasswd -A serena sports [root@RHEL4b ~]# su - serena [serena@RHEL4b ~]$ id harry uid=516(harry) gid=520(harry) groups=520(harry) [serena@RHEL4b ~]$ gpasswd -a harry sports Adding user harry to group sports [serena@RHEL4b ~]$ id harry uid=516(harry) gid=520(harry) groups=520(harry),522(sports) [serena@RHEL4b ~]$ tail -1 /etc/group sports:x:522:serena,venus,harry [serena@RHEL4b ~]$
section.para: Group administrators do not have to be a member of the group. They can remove themselves from a group, but this does not influence their ability to add or remove members.
section.screen: [serena@RHEL4b ~]$ gpasswd -d serena sports Removing user serena from group sports [serena@RHEL4b ~]$ exit
section.para: Information about group administrators is kept in the /etc/gshadow/etc/gshadow file.
To remove all group administrators from a group, use the gpasswd command to set an empty administrators list.

section.title: vigr
section.para: Similar to vipw, the vigrvigr(1) command can be used to manually edit the /etc/group file, since it will do proper locking of the file. Only experienced senior administrators should use vi or vigr to manage groups.
